title: Add support for interpolating null transform lists.
body: For consistency with [CSS3](http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-transforms/#animation), a null "from" or "to" transform list is replaced by an identity function list whose types match those of the non-null transform list.

title: Fix typo in comments: coallesce → coalesce.
Complex arguments for selection.insert/append
body:
Similar to #732, but with support for node & function arguments for both `selection.insert` _and_ `selection.append`.

My primary use case here is to easily insert nodes in some order (without having to sort the nodes after the fact)

I'm not sure if `core/selection-generation.js` is the right spot for that utility function, but couldn't find any good examples; is there a better spot for it?

title: Selection append support for naked nodes and functions
body:
Hello Mike, 

I'd like to collaborate selection-append support for naked dom nodes and for functions which, according to normal d3 style, will take the `(d, i)` data and index arguments and can return either a node or a qualified or unqualified name for a node.

title: Monotone_cubic_interpolation is implemented slightly incorrectly
body:
because the initial slopes were being set to the sum of the slopes of the secants instead of their average you can end up with wobbly line effects like:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/yzrdvux8kmvehzy/original-1.jpg
So with the slope corrected (the 1st commit) you get
https://www.dropbox.com/s/4h3ba09a3c8gxda/corrected.jpg

(note in the data there are only points at [2001,2002,2003,2004,2005,2006])

This implements the Fitsch-Carlson method which has a slight issue where it doesn't respect local minima in the data.
Note how in https://www.dropbox.com/s/4h3ba09a3c8gxda/corrected.jpg the curve falls below 2.0 just before x=2004. in the data the minimum point is at 2004 however the spline does not reflect that.

To resolve this you can set the initial slope to be 0 at local minima and maxima (the second commit)
see: https://www.dropbox.com/s/pep50cy9jsceyck/improved.jpg for the result.

title: Fixes custom timezone tests for Node.js 0.8.x.
body:
The process.env.TZ trick no longer seems to work. The fix automatically adds an offset to the minutes being set, relative to the current timezone. It assumes that the dates being tested in the scope are not in DST, since the offset is relative to the timezone offset at the epoch.

Fixes #718.

title: Minor optimisation for d3.layout.pack.
body: Uses the identity sin^2(x) + cos^2(x) = 1.

title: Add transition.filter. Fixes #726.
body: Behaves the same as selection.filter.

title: Interpolate "same type" transforms in isolation.
body:
For consistency with CSS3's 2D transforms, two transforms with the same number of transform functions and corresponding functions of the same type are treated differently: each transform function is interpolated in isolation.

This allows us to interpolate many transforms that contain constant functions in a more useful way, e.g.

```
"rotate(<variable>)translate(<constant>)"
```

The variable rotation angle would now be linearly interpolated on its own, keeping the constant translation vector constant.

title: New option for args to selection.append
body:
allows `selection.append(function)`. The function is expected to return
a node for each member of the selection.

title: Minor optimisation and Chrome bug workaround.
body:
There appears to be a [bug in Chrome](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=138552) causing the whole tab to crash when setting the following for a newly-created element without a non-empty class name.

``` js
svgNode.className.baseVal = "";
```

This fix is a minor optimisation: if the current class is empty then removing a class should be a no-op.  It also conveniently works around the Chrome bug.

title: Pass nested selection group index to event listeners
body: Not sure where in the documentation I discovered this (it's not typically mentioned) but in a nested selection, the "group" index is actually [passed to callbacks as the third argument](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/master/src/core/selection-each.js#L10). This fixes the `selection.on` code so it doesn't drop arguments from `selection.each`.

title: d3.time parsing: convert 2-digit years according to POSIX.
body: This is also the convention used by Python 1.5.2+. Values 69-99 are mapped to 1969-1999, and values 0–68 are mapped to 2000–2068.

title: Fix d3.geo.circle clipping.
body:
This uses a new algorithm, based on Weiler-Atherton. The difference is
that we only need to clip against a single line (the circle), so this
simplifies things somewhat. Rough summary:
1. For each ring in each polygon, intersect with the circle and generate
   an array of segments. This same routine is used on its own for
   LineString and MultiLineString features.
2. Since we're dealing with closed polygons, we check the first and last
   segment to see if they should be merged into one.
3. Create a circular linked list containing the intersection points, in
   clockwise order of their position on the circle. For each start
   point, include a reference to the end point.
4. Finally, traverse the linked list, starting with an entering
   intersection point, inserting the segment and then following the
   reference to the end point. Then, interpolate along the circle edge
   to the next (clockwise) point, which should always be an entering
   point, and repeat until the start point is reached. The resulting
   ring is added as a polygon.
5. Continue with step 3 until all entering points have been visited.

To do: assign holes to their correct polygons, perhaps using winding
numbers. At the moment holes are essentially added as separate polygons,
which works for drawing since they're in anticlockwise order.

Fixes #691.

title: Add Google Spreadsheet support to D3
body:
# Google Spreadsheet

Hi Mr. Bostock,

First I would like to thank you for your beautiful code. It is truly a work of art.
### The Problem

I work for a major Brazilian newspaper (Estadão) and others may have the same problem as me. Large companies do not allow to change the header of the server to do CORS, not without months of meetings. This can be a bit stressful. Sometimes we just want to create a visualization with few data and be able to maintain the data from time to time.
### The suggestion

I agree that in general terms is not a good idea to use JSONP. But in the case of GDocs maybe we could make an exception. This would allow, for example, that the samples included in the package operate without requiring a server. Great advantage for beginners. :)
### About the change

I wrote a first implementation of how this might work. It groups the two main ways that google allows to download data from the tables. Via feeds and SQL query (https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/querylanguage). So the client does not need to download the entire table at once. That first implementation has less than 50 lines, but I will try to reduce more.
### Requirements

The table must be configured as public. The first row of the table must have the column names.
#### Restrictions

Google Spreadsheet does not allow more than 20MB or 400.000 cells. So this strategy does not replace a good database.
## Usage

``` javascript
d3.gdocs ({
    url: "", //url and table key
    sql: "", //table selection [optional]
    as_feed: false //strategy used to download data [optional]
}, function (data) {
    //where magic happens
})
```
### Security

The URL is disassembled, reassembled and parsed with a single callback enabled and it will runs within the D3
### Testing

Using the technique of late-loading. Can we test this technique using the current HTML libraries of D3?

**TO-DO** _Include support for choose specific Sheets on table_

I hope that this addition can be useful

Thank you very much

Tcha-Tcho

title: Don't interpret double-pan as double-tap.
body:
Firstly, the last-touched-time was being set on touchend, even if a pan gesture had occurred. This caused a pan quickly followed by a single tap to be interpreted as a double-tap. In this fix, the time is only set on touchstart.

Secondly, the time is cleared on touchmove, so that a pan gesture cancels double-tap detection.

title: Fix #691: remove incorrect last interpolation step.
body:
For closed polygons, the last point should simply be connected to the first clipped point, rather than be clipped to the clipping circle.

Without this last step, the [Azimuthal grid](http://bl.ocks.org/3021474) still works fine, but you can see the inconsistent clip edge when slowly changing the x-origin in the world countries Azimuthal example, because this step is needed to handle closed polygons.

title: Add X-Requested-With to XMLHttpRequest's header
body:
This will fix the error when (if) server-side framework checks request header
before create respond as Ajax

title: Custom d3.svg.{area,line} interpolators.
body:
You can now specify a function as the interpolate property of a line or area,
allowing you to define custom interpolation behavior.

title: Add support for outer padding on rangeBands.
body:
Sometimes you want additional padding between the outer bands and the range
extent. Now you can.

title: Use shortest path for hue in d3.interpolateHsl.
body: Fixes #688.

title: Add d3.tsv for tab-separated values.
body:
This makes the previous d3.csv code a bit more generic via a d3_dsv (delimiter-
separated values) module generator. Fixes #501. (Thanks, @vlandham!)
